title: The day the film will lose its relevance, the world will be a happier place...
review: This is Daniel Blake, played by Dave Johns. For his doctor, he's a patient with a heart condition. For the Department of Work and Pensions, he's an entity, a number, an impersonal element that didn't pass the test that could earn him a disability pension. For his neighbor (Kema Sikazwe), he's a widower and sympathetic old curcumdgeon. And for us, he's a most resourceful and honest man, a product of the Baby Boom generation, a man who does things with his hands as efficiently as his heart and doesn't beg for money but only desires the insurance of a decent living. He's got pride and dignity, he's an old school chap caught in the midst of the dematerialized but no less obstructive (and destructive) bureaucracy,Watching poor Daniel entrapped in the pervert mechanisms of a system that deems him able to work and trying to claim his rights to office workers who remain deaf and blind to his explanations is painful to watch, but it's a cathartic experience nonetheless. We know we're not alone for as long as directors like Ken Loach will shed light on average people promised to a slow downfall because of bureaucratic technicalities, cinema will preserve its nobility. While Hollywood is busy making films about superheroes, here's a touching and minimalist drama that illustrates with the simple language of the camera the struggles of the little people, the forgotten entities of the liberal dream without drowning the material in an ocean of pathos.Indeed, Daniel is constantly active, he tries to reason his interviewers, the security guards, he learns how to use the Internet, and later, we see him helping Kathy, a single mother with two kids by fixing plumbery, crafting and simply making his presence indispensable. He's the handy man and the father-figure a house needs. His obstacle-course of a life allows us to discover the struggle of single mothers. Played by Hailey Squires, Kathy couldn't get her family allowances because she missed the bus and therefore her appointment. trying we also have a glimpse on the fate of a woman who can't get her allocations because she came late, Like Daniel, no one listens to her. Still, there's one worked played by Kate Rutter who restores our faith. They're not all heartless robots repeating the same mechanical shticks, but for her efforts to assist Daniel, her boss tells her off for setting a dangerous precedent. So much for the light of hope.This is not a neutral film, obviously, it's a powerful "J'Accuse" against the system and it's Ken Loach after all. But Loach and screenwriter Paul Laverty did their homework before starting shooting, collecting as many items of confidences to build their story. A man losing his disability pension because of a seizure during a meeting, another sanctioned for missing an appointment because of his father's funeral, hardly what Daniel and Kathy went through. Indeed, reality is as surrealistic as Asterix' "House That Sends You Mad". But you might lose a little more than your marbles here, money, dignity, life, you name them. Loach deliberately didn't chose a handicapped person because the case would be 'too' obvious, he picked two healthy-looking people to make their case more administratively ambiguous. From our POV, they're responsible enough, which makes their breakdowns more difficult to watch.So we get some harrowing moments such as Kathy opening a tin of beans in the Food Bank (an episode that would earn her daughter mockeries from her schoolmates), we see her shoplifting and almost pushed into the worst possible scenario job-wise and meanwhile Daniel is only forced to trick the system and asks for unemployment benefits. The catch is that he's got to endure these training sessions where they lecture you about these magical 'ten seconds' (and boy, I went through that), he gets insults from a man who genuinely wanted to hire and learned that he only did that to get allowance, and on the phone, Daniel can't even articulate a reason ... too rational to swallow the only medicine he can get. The closest to comedy is the running gag of the phone calls where you've got to endure Vivaldi for hours (again so true to life) and the ultimate breakdown moment where Daniel makes a temporary buzz by tagging his protest on a wall and even mention the music.That scene isn't shown like a triumph but the last burst of rebellious dignity from a man who always kept a low profile and tried to live normally in that world of nonsense. I wouldn't spoil what goes after that scene but in totally unglamorous and un-Dickensian fashion, that fits the depiction of the paupers' lives in Newcastle, Loach provides an extraordinary depiction of a system that is far sneakier than a real movie villain and that contaminated every town of the civilized world. The nightmares of job centers, these places where unemployed people must regularly register, wondering inside how come the people who work there have that job. And Loach reveals that some workers did tell them that they were forced to act that way, many felt ashamed, many didn't even stay, some were fired, which is like imagining former prison guards going to jail. I used the term "surrealist" but that fits the purpose of Loach who denounces the fact that these people are supposed to find jobs that don't exist and the real mockery is to make them believe that it's their fault, not enough motivation, not enough guts or a not so eye-catching resume. In the end, they're lazy, they're parasites, it's all their fault.Today, the pandemic is still going, we don't live, restaurant owners see their lifetime investments being dilapidated, but the government ensures us that it's our fault, for not respecting safety precautions. It is a tough world for the little ones, thankfully, Ken Loach is still here to defend all the Daniel Blakes, all the Kathies of the world. A well-deserved second Golden palm win!

title: A man's struggle and suffering portrayed convincingly
review: An honest and heart-wrenching film made by the renowned English director Ken Loach. He won the Palme d'Or in Cannes Film Festival for this movie and it also won the BAFTA for Outstanding British Film of the Year. It is one of the best films that came out in 2016. In my opinion, it deserved all the praise it received cause it affected me on a personal level and the feeling stayed for several days. Lots of research was done by the director and screenwriter Paul Laverty, his longtime collaborator before filming began. They interviewed people who worked in the Department of Work and Pensions as well as the beneficiaries and incorporated their experiences.A man, suffering under the system and being denied his rights. I thought these types of things only happened in my country, but disappointingly this problem is everywhere. The director presents the starkly realistic struggle of a carpenter, Daniel Blake (Dave Johns), applying for support allowance. He befriends a single mother, Katie (Hayley Squires), with two kids also struggling due to the faulty state system. We see their friendship develop and helping each other through difficult situations, but the hope for justice proves futile.The characters, the acting, and the dialogues are so realistic that it resembles a documentary rather than a film. The acting by the actors is nothing short of brilliant. Dave Johns's portrayal of a proud, honest and compassionate character is one of the best, and I sympathized with his predicament. I clapped for him while watching an act of rebelliousness by him. The direction is pure and Ken Loach's talent for creating emotional moments is praiseworthy.The screenplay by Paul Laverty is original and avoids unnecessary cliches. The colors have a tinge of gray representing the cold-hearted world. The film elicits genuine sympathy for the characters and does not cheat our emotions by using sentimental music, in fact, there is no background score at all. The actors do the hard job of making us feel emotionally drenched. It is a movie that needs to be seen at least once.

title: What a lost opportunity!
review: I should like 'I Daniel Blake'. As an educated but proudly working class liberal, the message should resonate and move me, but the film left me with strong feelings of disappointment and lost opportunities, not about the subject but about the film. Firstly, there is a distinct reluctance to portray the central characters as ordinary working class. I can understand the reticence in perhaps following old clichés in relation to the working class - as we are often unfairly portrayed as caricatures and overwhelmingly uneducated. However, the portrayal of the central characters as having hidden talents or aspirations of higher education are clumsy and patronising and not a little cynical. I felt the film was appealing to the affluent middle class liberal and that their affection for the characters could not be garnered without the addition of this extra potential. I would have found the story a lot more believable if the characters had been far more ordinary, who just survive without the fall-back option of bettering themselves with Open University aspirations. Also, Daniel's obvious artistic talents make it unlikely that he would need to sell his furniture to survive. My main annoyance at the film however is the broad strokes it takes with the storyline - the employees at the various government agencies are portrayed as almost universally heartless. Having experience of unemployment and dealing with these kinds of people, this is not my experience. Also, the oldest cliché in the book, of the mother having no choice but to go into prostitution was the final straw for me. It was not a little patronising and insulting to me as a woman to portray this as a natural progression. In short, I was ready to love this film, but it is clumsy, cliché ridden and only appeals to those having an isolated affection for the working class and does the subject matter (which deserves proper attention) no favours whatsoever.

title: Dan's Labyrinth
review: Ken Loach must finally be mellowing, since we actually get only occasional glimpses of the relentless Kafkaesque nightmare that is negotiating Britain's benefit system in the 21st Century.In his determination to humanise his central characters Loach devotes far too much time to Daniel Blake's resilience, good humour, and friendship with Katie (whose story provides more than sufficient material for a separate movie of her own; and as a pretty but vulnerable young woman the film graphically demonstrates is prey to even more insidious forms of abuse in her own right), and remarkably little to the profligate amount of time squandered on negotiating the intractable bureaucratic maze of form-filling, queuing and listening to Vivaldi that blights the lives of him and countless others.Overworked, badly-paid drones impatiently tell Daniel to "Just Listen!!" while never actually listening to HIM; and those who deviate from the script by attempting to be sympathetic or helpful can expect immediately to be pounced upon and upbraided by their managers for wasting time. But we only fleetingly see chores like the 9 a.m. CV preparation class whose true function is just to provide yet another hoop for him to jump through; and we never see the endless hours spent on public transport during the rush hour getting to and from these mischievously time-consuming impositions (invariably scheduled first thing in the morning, and woe betide anyone who shows up late).

title: Its message is good, but the movie is a chore
review: I agree with the politics and the moral sentiments of this film wholeheartedly, but the film itself is rather mediocre. It seems ironic to me that this is the kind of fare that could only be appreciated by festivalgoers and the attendees of prestigious art cinemas--people who, on average, have expendable incomes far surpassing those of the characters populating the film. I grew up in poverty and on welfare; nobody in my family would have ever spent their precious free time watching something as tedious as this.The general lack of verisimilitude in the performances is perhaps what made it such a slog for me. Most of the non-professional bit actors--even though they're just supposed to be garden variety social workers, security guards, and such saying fairly commonplace things--seem like they're reading from a script overloaded with symbolic messaging. There's nothing more boring to me than cinéma-vérité that can't quite nail the vérité part. I'd rather just watch a documentary; a real social worker doing her job is far more interesting to watch than a bad actor pretending to be one, even if they're technically saying and doing the same things. Dave Johns, in what I gather is his first real dramatic role (I'm American and have never seen him before, but I gather he's well-known as a stand-up comedian in England), seems like he's reading lines from a page most of the time, trying his hardest to avoid looking at the camera. Hayley Squires is decent, even if her character is a cliche from a nineteenth century naturalistic novel, and the two young actors who play her kids are also quite convincing, but that's about it.It was far too on-the-nose, predictable, saccharine, and tedious for my taste. Its heart is in the right place, but a documentary film or a decent long-form magazine article would have probably succeeded better at engaging me in the issues.

They are both hard working lovely people with good hearts, just trying to find work and in Katie's case, feed a family. It made me sick in my soul to see how they are treated in so many places, how unbending the system is. And then, the people that do help like the shop owner, the sneaker neighbor and the kind people in the food bank, they nourish your soul back again. It's just hard. The embarrassment and humility. I don't think this is the average person in the system in the UK, but I think even if it's only 10% of the people, it's far too many. I know this film isn't for everybody. It's difficult subject matter presented in a linear way. The acting is incredible. Some of the most brilliant delivery, of the most heart wrenching common-man dialogue. The scenes/sets, direction, script - it's all bloody brilliant in the most relatable accessible of ways. This is a champion job for the every man.

title: Remarkable and essential.
review: British director Ken Loach isn't known for politically subtle films; his stories are ones which grounded in one political worldview, promoting and expounding it from a variety of angels. That's not to say he's necessarily heavy-handed; but he runs that risk on occasions. Approaching this film, aware that it was his state of the (British) nation address from the point of view of people lost in a labyrinthine benefits system, I was expecting something I would be naturally sympathetic to but possibly alienated from due to what I expected to be broad-brush strokes. I was wrong; it's Loach's most nuanced and delicate film, telling a simple story with slowly simmering rage. A widowed man is signed off sick from work due to a heart condition; as he attempts to claim the benefits he needs he befriends a single mother and her children as they too seek the support the state should be giving them. Though the script is compelling, the real strength of the film is in its silences and counterpoints; the personal care of the food bank volunteers against the largely dispassionate, impersonal government employees. This results in the films most moving scene - a visit to a food bank where a combination of hunger and receiving compassion tip a desperate, nearly crushed woman in to an act of quiet desperation that's heartbreaking to watch. It's to the film's immense credit that it doesn't drift into anti-climax afterwards; yet neither is there a cheap, easy victory or moment of false hope. Hope is there, but it walks a vulnerable line of being extinguished by the system designed to serve the very people lost under the weight rules and regulations. It's a story of the people who fall through the cracks; it reminded me of Dickens' urgent, prophetic tales of urban poverty and never ending legal wranglings - and the film does not suffer from such lofty comparison. We're left asking: do we contribute to such systems' oppression and suffering, or do we seek out those who are lost, sit with them, listen to them, walk with them? It's a film of difficult questions and few answers; but that is moving, satisfying, funny and eloquent for all that.

title: Heartwrenching, striking and ultimately real
review: I have never given a film a 10 on this website. A 10 would imply perfection and that should not exist. About an hour into I, Daniel Blake I paused the film and said that it was flawless, by the end I had some tiny quibbles that would make it a 9.5 if I had my nastiest, most quibble-orientated, pedantic critic hat on. IMDB does not allow fractional star scores, it deserved the 10.The performances by David Johns and Hayley Squires are magnificent, the screenwriting by Paul Laverty is wonderful. The film pulls you in, absorbs you and refuses to allow you to look away. The brilliance is not that it is harrowing, not that it shocks or sickens, it is that it's relateable.I'm reminded of Requiem for a Dream, a film that grips by the sheer horror that it depicts, but in I, Daniel Blake there is no horror of the abstract, every character could be someone you walk past on the street on any day of your life. The gut punch comes from the fact there is no gut punch, the normality is infinitely stronger.This film is beautiful, tragic, desperate, funny and ultimately speaks to people trying to live their lives. Instead of continuing to gush all I will say is watch this, you will have no regrets.

title: Daniel Blake gives up paid work for voluntary work...
review: ...he's a skilled carpenter who suffers a heart attack and is recovering while taking drugs to prevent a further attack. Instead of asking for light duties he leaves paid employment to help a neighbor by working as a handyman doing up their council house.Gradually he grapples with computers and the digital world that was passing him by and puts together his CV that is good enough to earn him a job interview but he turns it down!Meanwhile the neighbor he is helping is starving herself to share the family's food with Daniel. She is leafleting her neighborhood for cleaning work but Dan is not selling his handyman or carpentry skills to earn some much needed cash.Meanwhile the DWP's digital bureaucracy grinds exceedingly fine with rules that must be obeyed for claimants fulfilling their personal commitments to receive welfare benefits and to avoid sanction.Unused to such discipline and computers Dan is sucked down into a spiral of despair.The film had me screaming at the TV for Dan to sell his handyman services while continuing to help his neighbor. At no time did he stop work but he simply didn't take control of his life.I guess that I was meant to feel sorry for him but I couldn't.
